xxl.core.io
Class ObjectToBlockCursor

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor
      xxl.core.io.ObjectToBlockCursor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator, Cursor
public class ObjectToBlockCursor
extends AbstractCursor

This class transforms objects into a sequence of Blocks. The objects are delivered by an input Iterator. The Blocks are having a header (which can be used to build up a linked list of Blocks).

The last (nth) Block may not be full whereas the first n-1 Blocks are completely filled (except empty space inside the header). To get the number of bytes which are used inside the last Block seen by next, call the method getNumberOfBytesInsideLastBlock().

To go the way back use the class MultiBlockInputStream.

Constructor Detail

ObjectToBlockCursor

public ObjectToBlockCursor(Iterator it,
                           Converter converter,
                           int blockSize,
                           int headerSize,
                           int maxElementSize,
                           Function writeLength)
Creates a new ObjectToBlockIterator.

Parameters:
it - input Iterator delivering Objects.
converter - converter used to convert the objects of the input Iterator.
blockSize - size of the Blocks of the resulting sequence.
headerSize - size of the header of the Blocks which is left free.
maxElementSize - size of the biggest input Object to be converted in bytes (at least).
writeLength - Function which is called for every new created Block (parameters: Block and length which is used inside the Block as Integer). This function can be used to encode the real length of the Block inside the Block. If writeLength==null then no function call is performed.

getNumberOfBytesInsideLastBlock

public long getNumberOfBytesInsideLastBlock()
Returns the number of bytes which are used inside the last Block returned with next.

Returns:
the number of bytes (-1 if there has not been a next call before).

main

public static void main(String[] args)
Use case which serializes Strings to Blocks and prints them. Remember: each String conversion contains the length of the String inside the first two bytes.

Parameters:
args - The command line options are ignored here.
